head.title: 3 in the Inner Circle Of Clinton's Defense

hedline.hl1: 3 in the Inner Circle Of Clinton's Defense

block.p: In contrast to his normal style of reaching out to as many advisers as possible and weighing a wide variety of opinions, President Clinton is relying heavily on a close circle of three private lawyers in dealing with his legal problems. The three, David E. Kendall, Mickey Kantor and Nicole K. Seligman, are described by current and former White House officials as enjoying Mr. Clinton's total trust.

In contrast to his normal style of reaching out to as many advisers as possible and weighing a wide variety of opinions, President Clinton is relying heavily on a close circle of three private lawyers in dealing with his legal problems. The three, David E. Kendall, Mickey Kantor and Nicole K. Seligman, are described by current and former White House officials as enjoying Mr. Clinton's total trust.

But the decision to keep the sensitive issues in a very small circle has been driven less by that trust than by court rulings. Those rulings have held he does not enjoy the confidentiality of the lawyer-client relationship with Government employees, including Bruce Lindsey, one of his most trusted aides, and Lanny Breuer, a special White House counsel who appeared before the grand jury yesterday.
